content.description:
Oro, si quis adhuc precibusprex, precis, f.: prayer locus, exueexuo, -ere = muto, -are mentem.
Te propter LibycaeLibycus, -a, -um, adj.: from Libya (a country in north Africa) gentes NomadumNomas, -adis, m. or f.: Numidian; someone from Numidia (a country in north Africa)que tyrannityrannus, -i, m. = rex, regis 
odereodere = oderunt, “(they) hate”, infensiinfensus, -a, -um, adj. = inimicus, -a, -um TyriiTyrius, -a, -um, adj.: from Tyre; te propter eundem 
exstinctus pudorpudor, -is, m.: honor, -oris et, qua sola sidera adibam, 

fama prior. Cui me moribundammoribundus, -a, -um, adj.: dying deseris hospes 
(hoc solum nomen quoniamquoniam, conj.: since de coniuge restatresto, -are = maneo, -ere)? 
Quid moror? An mea PygmalionPygmalion, -onis, m.: Pygmalion dum moenia frater 
destruatdestruo, -ere: to demolish aut captam ducat Gaetulus IarbasGaetulus Iarbas = Iarbas? 
Saltemsaltem, adv.: at least si qua mihi de te susceptasusceptus, -a, -um, adj.: conceived fuisset 

ante fugam subolessuboles, -is, f.: offspring, si quis mihi parvulusparvulus, -a, -um, adj. = parvus, -a, -um aulaaula, -ae, f. = domus, -i 
luderet Aeneas, qui te tamen ore referret, 
non equidem omnino capta ac deserta viderer.
content.question: In lines 7-8 (Quid...Iarbas), Dido suggests, because of her current situation, that

choices.label: her walls will delay Pygmalion and Iarbas from reaching Carthage
she wants to kill her brother while she remains in Carthage
she will soon face certain challenges to her power

content.answer: she will soon face certain challenges to her power

unit.text: 5: Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 4, 6, 7, 11, and 12
